entry.title: Interview with a Baker - Will Rose
entry.summary: In our “Interview with a Baker” series, we ask artisanal bakers from…
entry.content:
In our “Interview with a Baker” series, we ask artisanal bakers from across the globe with different backgrounds to answer twenty questions about their experience with sourdough and baking in general. The questions the bakers answer range on topics from their baking history to specific techniques they use in their bread making process.

Hello Baker. Tell us a little about yourself, your background and who you are.

I'm Will, I’m 20 Years old and I am a professional baker.

How can we find you on social media?

Instagram: ducky.the.baker

Do you have a website or blog or perhaps a video sharing platform you'd like to share?

No at the moment, there is potential.

Where in the world are you located?

UK

How long have you been making bread, and specifically sourdough bread?

3 years.

What inspired you to explore sourdough?

I dropped out of school and decided to become a baker. My first experience was a 4 Week Basic Bread Course where I first learnt about sourdough. Once I discovered Real Bread there was no going back to supermarket bread.

What has been the hardest part of learning how to make sourdough for you?

The ability to adapt to and understand all of the external factors that affect your bread. There is a few.

What is your personal style with regards to making sourdough bread?

Most of my sourdough is done at work so my style is whatever I’m told to do. But I like to keep things simple.

What’s your routine for refreshing and maintaining your starter?

Because I bake bread everyday for work i prefer to bake other things at home, meaning I leave my starter in the fridge and refresh it once a week. 50% water, 50% White Wheat flour.

How soon before mixing your dough do you start your autolyse?

30 minutes minimum but beyond that you could leave it for as long as you want, think a good time is maybe 1-2 hours.
 

What is your favorite grain to work with?

Wheat, it’s the standard bread to work with. It’s nice and soft and elastic and fun to shape unlike some other grains which although look and taste great are not as fun to work with.

What is your preferred technique for developing gluten in your dough once it’s mixed together?

Basic stretch and folds and then I lift the whole thing up so it tucks under itself. Just makes it look neater and creates a smaller surface area when you tip it out.

Do you prefer the ambient or retarded method of baking?

I’m happy with both. Retarded creates a firmer dough which is better for its final shape when it comes out of the oven and for slashing. Also with retarded it’s fermented for longer so it has a better flavour but also creates bigger air pockets which although look nice I don’t like because butter just seeps onto my plate.

How long do you let your dough proof for?

Very wide variety of timings for different doughs. In professional bakeries we have guideline timings but these are absolute guidelines and we ultimately decide when it is sufficiently proved. But a standard time for most dough is 1-3 hours.

What do you use to score your bread?

3 different tools: there are many more, all good for specific things. 
*basic serrated slashing knife 
*basic straight lame with razor blade 
*WireMonkeyShop UFO Corbeau
 

How do you bake your typical bread? (Dutch oven, steam oven, loaf pan…)

At work we have steam injected ovens, at home Dutch oven, because most home ovens can’t contain sufficient steam.

What is your favorite use for sourdough discard?

Not tried it myself yet but I think pancakes, crumpets are common ones.

How do you see yourself expanding your sourdough skills in the future? Are there new skills you want to master?

Ancient grains and flour blends.
 

Are there any projects you are working on that you’d like to share with us?

I’m always teaching myself new skills at home, you can see on my Instagram.

What advice do you have for new bakers?

Are you having fun? if so then it doesn’t matter if your product looks good or not, baking is about fun and for a lot of people relaxation, especially in bread making, sure having a nice end result is great but the process of making bread is the fun part. Also keep practicing. One day it clicks and what you found hard is now second nature. Read lots of books and find different techniques and pick your favourite one. This will help a lot, there’s lots of different techniques that give the same result.

entry.title: Interview with a Baker - Doug
entry.summary: In our “Interview with a Baker” series, we ask artisanal bakers from…
entry.content:
In our “Interview with a Baker” series, we ask artisanal bakers from across the globe with different backgrounds to answer twenty questions about their experience with sourdough and baking in general. The questions the bakers answer range on topics from their baking history to specific techniques they use in their bread making process.

 

Hello Baker. Tell us a little about yourself, your background and who you are.

What's up! My name is Doug, I'm 35 and I live in Hilton Head Island, SC. I'm originally from Arizona, but have lived in multiple places across the country over the span of my crazy life. I've been married to my incredible wife Ivy for 7 years, we have a beautiful 5 year old daughter Phoebe and a Tasmanian devil, I mean chocolate lab named Rocksie. During the day, I am the Plant Health Services Manager for a big local landscape company. At night, I am a baking-obsessed madman. Baking is quite a new thing for me and it takes a bit of explanation, so I apologize in advance. I have no history of baking in my lifetime or my family's. Everyone who knows me has been befuddled on where this all has come from. Well, buckle up. (Deep inhale) In February of 2017, I had finally admitted that I was an alcoholic. I entered myself into a rehab facility, sought help, found my spirituality and began the long journey of a new life in sobriety. I have now been gratefully sober for over two years. Now that I didn't have my best friend anymore (alcohol), I realized that I really didn't have any hobbies or activities I liked doing besides playing golf. Well with a 5-year old and a marriage I would like to keep, finding 4+ hours to go do something by myself is usually not in the realm of possibility. My wife and I have very different schedules. I go to work when everyone is still asleep, I come home and she goes to work, she comes home and I'm asleep (more like in bed, but you get it). Essentially, I'm alone a lot (after 9pm when my daughter is asleep) and bored. Fast-forward to December of 2018 and I discover "The Great British Baking Show" or as I now call "The Cause of My New Addiction...Show". I couldn't stop watching it and felt this growing urge inside me to give it a try. I was raised with the notion that I could do anything, so being the psychopath that I am, I gave it a whirl and well, let's just say I dove in head first. I was baking everything and anything I could. Cakes, cookies, babka's, entremets, you name it, I was going nuts. My wife was starting to think there was something wrong with me (she didn't say it, but I could tell, she had that "look" she would give me when I would still be up baking something at 2am). Then I discovered sourdough and there was just something about it that enraptured me. It seemed fun, exciting, challenging, all the boxes were being checked that get me excited. By New Year's, Deebo was already born and heading towards his first loaf of sourdough. Deebo is my starter. Go see "Friday" with Ice Cube and it will make sense. In 2 months, I have converted my kitchen into a full-blown sourdough haven. My oven is not just a place to bake things, but also a warm home for Deebo and a dough proofer (until my Brod & Taylor one comes in the mail!). There is at least 2-3 loaves on our counter at all times. So at this point I should admit something to you. I don't really like bread. Or cake. Or cookies. I know, weird. Why do I keep doing it then? There is no feeling like I've ever experienced, like that of when I give someone something I baked and it makes them smile. My history has been that of causing pain and destruction, to be able to reverse that and make people smile and feel good... I'm actually tearing up writing about it. I bake because it is my way of giving back. It may not seem like much, but it means more to me than anyone will ever understand.

How can we find you on social media?

You can find me on Instagram @dfreshbaking. The nickname Dougie Fresh has followed me since I was a kid. I used to hate it, but everywhere I go people start calling me that so, why not go with it? I do have Facebook but I don't post a lot of my bakes on there. I'm sure it will change in the future but for now I just use Instagram. You can also e-mail me, dfreshbaking@gmail.com.

Do you have a website or blog or perhaps a video sharing platform you'd like to share?

Not yet, I would like to try someday though.

Where in the world are you located?

Hilton Head Island, SC, USA.

How long have you been making bread, and specifically sourdough bread?

I made my first loaf of bread in December of 2018 and my first loaf of sourdough in January of 2019. A newbie.

What inspired you to explore sourdough?

It seemed like the mountain-top of bread making. I liked the challenge of making a starter, fermenting the dough, shaping, scoring, all of it. I'm into processes and following instructions. I'm that guy that will yell at someone (my wife/daughter) when they begin to make something without reading the instructions first. Can thank my father for that one. I love how much science is involved and I love how so much of it is unknown. I love the anticipation of what it will look like when I take off the lid of my combo-cooker. What's the crumb going to look like? I'm just obsessed with everything about it.

What has been the hardest part of learning how to make sourdough for you?

Finding enough time to make it. Let me rephrase that, finding a way to make it all the time. It has been quite difficult to contain my urge to bake solely on weekends. Through trial and error, I have now mastered how to bake during the work week. I could potentially lose my job, but I found a way! Seriously though, the hardest part has been to not do it. To not read about it at work, or post something at work, or run home during my lunch break to make an autolyse. I told you, I'm obsessed.

What is your personal style with regards to making sourdough bread?

I can't say I have a style yet because I am in the beginning stages of this endeavor. I would say I have a tendency to experiment. I am currently enjoying playing with different flavors and what I can actually put in bread. Like chocolate, cherries, cardamom and cayenne pepper (my 4C's bread) or like currently I am playing with a "nutella" loaf using chocolate, honey and hazelnut flour. So if I had to pick one, I would say my style is to challenge what sourdough bread can be, while still being traditional in how its made.

What’s your routine for refreshing and maintaining your starter?

After quite a bit of, well, experimenting. I have chosen a schedule that works best for my day. I feed Deebo twice a day during the week and will bump that up to 3x on the weekends because I'm making so much. I actually have two starters, one white and one wheat/rye. I was feeding both daily, but the upkeep and time got a bit consuming so I will now maintain one during the week while the other is in the fridge and rotate them on the weekend. Its so much easier. I also keep a big jar of discard in the freezer.

How soon before mixing your dough do you start your autolyse?

My goal is 2 hours. My reality has been anywhere from 20 min. to 6 hours (the 6 hour one was, well, interesting). It all depends on when I bake and what is happening around me i.e. daughter is home/awake, laundry, dishes, clean the house, etc.

What is your favorite grain to work with?

I'm enjoying spelt quite a bit, but there is a lot I have yet to try so to pick a favorite would be unfair. I am currently giving sprouted wheat a try. There isn't a whole lot of variety down here where I am. Other Instagram baker's are my inspiration and amazon is my grocery store.

What is your preferred technique for developing gluten in your dough once it’s mixed together?

Depends on the dough. A heavy whole-grain, low hydration dough I'm strechin' and foldin'. A bread or all-purpose based dough at 80% and up hydration, I doing my coil folds. I also like to develop strength in my mixing, particularly with high-hydration dough. My preferred mixing method is the Rubaud method. It is so relaxing and meditative, not to mention it's clean and quite effective.

Do you prefer the ambient or retarded method of baking?

I've tried both and greatly prefer to do a very cold retard. I crank the fridge down to about 38F (my wife loves that) to try and get those deep, deep notes fermented goodness in there.

How long do you let your dough proof for?

I aim for 6-6.5 hours at 78F. My first loaf was very under-proofed and ever since then (plus some amazing advise other Instagram bakers) I pay very close attention to temperature and the way it looks. 9/10 it takes 6 hours.

What do you use to score your bread?

I use a razor blade jammed onto a coffee-stirrer and just a plain straight razor blade. I do, however, have a Tyler's Wire Monkey UFO Zero lame headed my way soon! Pretty stoked for that one to arrive.

How do you bake your typical bread? (Dutch oven, steam oven, loaf pan…)

I use my Lodge combo cooker for a majority of my bakes. I'm finding I need to watch my batard size though because sometimes they get smushed in there. I will pre-heat at 500F, then take out the bottom pan, take the dough out of the fridge and slide it onto the pan, score (carefully) and bake covered for 20 min. I then lower the temp to about 450, take off the cover, give the little guy a spin and bake for another 10-15 min depending on size. I have found that I need to turn the temp down a little further on some loaves, as they tend to get a tad too dark on top. I have a "steam your home oven set-up", but my cheap pizza stone cracked. So when my real one gets here, I will set it up again because I would like to start baking two at a time. My set-up consists of an old cast-iron pan filled with lava rocks, the soon-to-be-here baking stone and an old, large mixing bowl. I preheat the rocks and stone, then pour a cup and a half hot water right when I put in the dough. Then the lid goes on, slightly over-hanging the stone over the lava rocks, to catch the steam. It works great, I just need my freakin' stone to get here.

What is your favorite use for sourdough discard?

Cinnamon rolls. They are really simple to make (thanks to Maurizio and The Perfect Loaf, go to his site, its a MUST) and are a great vessel for different flavors. Pancakes are amazing too. I can never eat a normal pancake again!

How do you see yourself expanding your sourdough skills in the future? Are there any new skills you want to master?

I am constantly exploring, reading and watching anything I can. I've read Tartine by Chad Robertson which is great, but I am currently reading "Open Crumb Mastery: For the Intermediate Sourdough Baker" by Trevor J. Wilson. It's an e-book and it is a game changer. I have learned so much about proper fermentation, dough handling, working with wet dough, shaping wet dough, basically all of the tools and science behind achieving an open crumb. Its awesome. It is like the title says though, I wouldn't start out with this book because its not a beginners guide. But if you want to take your bread to that next level? Buy it.

Are there any projects you are working on that you’d like to share with us?

I wish. I have plenty of ideas swimming around, but I'm really just going along for the ride and not trying to control it. I'm going to bake my tail off, learn, share and see where this all takes me. So far? I'm diggin' it.

What advice do you have for new bakers?

Do not get discouraged! If something doesn't work? Go back and try and find out why, then try again. Keep it simple to start. Focus on consistently baking a certain recipe and then once the training wheels are off, go for it. Don't be afraid! It's bread. It has four ingredients. But the things you can do with those four simple things is amazing. Keeping notes is definitely important. I have been halfway through a ferment and forgot when my last stretch and fold was or what time I added the salt. Write everything down, it also helps when you need to make adjustments too. Lastly, have fun! It shouldn't be scary and intimidating. If a recovering alcoholic who should probably be in a mental institution can make sourdough. Why can't you?

entry.title: Interview with a Baker - Simon
entry.summary: In our “Interview with a Baker” series, we ask artisanal bakers from across the…
entry.content:
In our “Interview with a Baker” series, we ask artisanal bakers from across the globe with different backgrounds to answer twenty questions (Editor's note: some questions were deleted because they were already answered in other parts) about their experience with sourdough and baking in general. The questions the bakers answer range on topics from their baking history to specific techniques they use in their bread making process.

Hello Baker. Tell us a little about yourself, your background and who you are.

I am 54 years old, run a small building company in the UK, I am a father of two sons and a fantastic (!) husband to my lovely wife. I love contact sports and I love all rustic/natural methods of cooking. I have learnt lots of skills from you tube & have far too many hobbies. 

How can we find you on social media?

Instagram only @life_of_si

Do you have a website or blog or perhaps a video sharing platform you'd like to share?

No. 

How long have you been making bread, and specifically sourdough bread?

I have been making bread for around four years, sourdough around 8 months. 

What inspired you to explore sourdough?

Instagram (Editor's note: We both know who inspired you) & my fabulous sourdough family.

What has been the hardest part of learning how to make sourdough for you?

Hydration. 

What is your personal style with regards to making sourdough bread?

I don’t have any hard & fast rules and I am constantly trying different methods.

What’s your routine for refreshing and maintaining your starter?

Starter is kept in a kilner jar without the rubber seal, I keep it in the fridge from Sunday morning until Thursday morning, the starter would have been fed before it went into the fridge bottom shelf with 200g starter, 200g water & 200g flour, no hard and fast rule on which flour at present.
 

How soon before mixing your dough do you start your autolyse?

1.5 hours. Again no hard & fast rule; has been up to 4 hours.

What is your favorite grain to work with?

Really still experimenting but rustic country grains, but I really enjoy mixing grains & experimenting.

What is your prefered technique for developing gluten in your dough once it’s mixed together?

Definately stretch & fold.

Do you prefer the ambient or retarded method of baking?

Retarded all day long.

How long do you let your dough proof for?

This varies and takes some explaining, we run a log burner through the winter & our house is really warm, so I was using the no knead method for 18 hours, then shaping & placing in the banneton then refrigerated overnight to bake first thing in the morning but I found this left me with a bit of a weak loaf so now I’m now practicing autolyse for 1.5 hours, mixing my starter into the water, mixing the dough together & leaving to sit for 3 hours, then stretch & found every hour until I’m happy that the dough is full of energy.

What do you use to score your bread?

Lets take this question back a click or two. I was using an extremely sharp bread knife, then graduated to a builders knife (a Stanley knife) then for Christmas my wife bought me a plastic lame but I found it to be too flimsy, so last week I made one out of walnut & it’s perfect for me. I’m sure I’ll be sticking with it.
 

How do you bake your typical bread? (Dutch oven, steam oven, loaf pan…)

Dutch oven, loaf pan, pizza tray but my favourite being my outside brick oven directly on the oven floor, this is the skill I’m determined to master.

What is your favorite use for sourdough discard?

Trying to encourage others. I've giving loads to people in the sourdough world.

How do you see yourself expanding your sourdough skills in the future? Are there new skill you want to master?

I’m really trying to get my structure better, and I have a sneaking feeling that my starter flavour will improve as it ages, that’s what I’m really looking forward to.

What advice do you have for new bakers?

Don’t be afraid to ask, don’t be afraid to experiment, don’t be disheartened when you fail, but strut around like a peacock when you get it right (Editor's note: not that much old man).
 
Editor: If you follow both Simon and myself, you'll understand the references I've made. I refrained myself quite a bit.

entry.title: Interview with a Baker - Mark & Grace
entry.summary: In our “Interview with a Baker” series, we ask artisanal bakers from…
entry.content:
In our “Interview with a Baker” series, we ask artisanal bakers from across the globe with different backgrounds to answer twenty questions about their experience with sourdough and baking in general. The questions the bakers answer range on topics from their baking history to specific techniques they use in their bread making process.

Hello Baker. Tell us a little about yourself, your background and who you are.

We are a Dad and Daughter team, Mark is 46 and Grace is 12. Grace is in Year 7 at High School and Mark works in the cheese wholesale industry as a Procurement manager. Basically overseeing a team who buys cheese and biscuits.

How can we find you on social media?

You can find us on Instagram as @him_and_miss. So far that's our only SM platform.

Do you have a website or blog or perhaps a video sharing platform you'd like to share?

Not at the moment but we have considered doing something one day.

Where in the world are you located?

Just outside of Melbourne, Australia. 

How long have you been making bread, and specifically sourdough bread?

As a team we have been baking sourdough since Jan 12, 2018. Mark has tried to do it on and off for about 20 years but could never get anything to work so he kept giving up.

What inspired you to explore sourdough?

It all started when Grace asked if we could bake some bread. I suggested that we could give sourdough a go. I'm an ex chef and we like to teach the kids how to cook. I thought lets not just do it with commercial yeast but the traditional way. So that morning we peeled a potato, mixed some flour and water with the potato peels and then we waited. That afternoon I had a panic attack as I remembered that I'd never been able to get it to work. I thought, what have I done. This will be a failure. So over the next two weeks while we kept feeding the starter, I secretly read and watched so many YouTube videos to make sure it would have the best possible outcome.

What has been the hardest part of learning how to make sourdough for you?

Our biggest challenge was shaping. Learning the different techniques that make a dough into a round, or an oval and working with high hydration doughs. We struggled a lot at the start. Grace was the one who was more delicate and I'd watch her shape beautiful round loaves and I had flat ones. It took awhile to work it out but she was less rough with the dough. I tended to rush it thinking it had to be done quick and I always knocked the air out of them. We are both much faster now but we have learnt good techniques that get the results.

What is your personal style with regards to making sourdough bread?

We are still pretty new to it all so we try to keep to one or two recipes and get to know them well. We try different methods of scoring etc. to see what it does and how it affects our baking, We've gone from round bannetons to oval and we love the different shape of the oval.

What’s your routine for refreshing and maintaining your starter?

We tend to bake every few days so we refresh with 50:50 ratio of flour and water and usually add enough to create the starter we'll require for the next bake. We tend to keep around 50grams of starter at a time.

How soon before mixing your dough do you start your autolyse?

We try to aim for a couple of hours of autolyse if we are planning ahead and aren't in a rush. Sometimes if we are running out of bread and we need to bake, we will throw everything in at once, leave it on the kitchen table for the whole day and Grace will come home from school and start folding. We shape before bed and into bannetons in the fridge and bake at 5:30am.

What is your favorite grain to work with?

We haven't had a lot of different grains to work with, but we do have a semi local grain grower and miller who uses spitfire wheat. We were able to get some flour to work with and its amazing. We just wish we had better access to buying it closer to us.

What is your preferred technique for developing gluten in your dough once it’s mixed together?

We've recently moved to coil folds and love it. It seems to work extremely well and give an airy loaf. I especially like how it seems to pick the dough up off the sides of the container and makes for less clean up. 

Do you prefer the ambient or retarded method of baking?

If we have planned in advance to bake bread we always use the retarded method. It give a greater scope of time to work with it. Of course if we are in a rush the ambient is our fall back method and sometimes life gets in the way and we use both. 

How long do you let your dough proof for?

It really depends on how the dough feels. We are really trying to get a good feel of how the dough is going so we can understand better the differences in flours or temperature etc. If we had to nail a time we'd say 4-5 hrs and then usually overnight in the bannetons for a 12 hour snooze,

What do you use to score your bread?

Recently we purchased a UFO Bread Journey Lame - Anna Gabur design which is amazing to work with. Previously, it was one of those razor blade on a stick type of lames. We need to do a bake with the new lame and try some of the fancy designs we see on Instagram. I don't think it will become something we do often but it would be fun to have a go. At the moment we are just trying to get a good ear,

How do you bake your typical bread? (Dutch oven, steam oven, loaf pan…)

We started with a small dutch oven and then I was gifted a second larger one by my wo
rk colleagues. I think it was a plan for me to take more bread into work. We had lots of requests for our bread and we needed to work out something more efficient. We discovered via Instagram that small micro bakery ovens exist and we purchased a Rofco B10. It makes life so much easier and with it hooked up to a smart power plug we can get it to turn on at 4am to heat up without us needing to wake up.
 
 
 

 

What is your favorite use for sourdough discard?

We rarely ever have any discard. We keep such a small amount of our starter. We only add enough when we refresh for the next bake so we haven't really ever tried any discard recipes.

How do you see yourself expanding your sourdough skills in the future? Are there new skill you want to master?

Grace: To get faster at shaping. We watch videos of professional bakers and they work so quick. 
 
Mark: Baguettes. I want to master baguettes. We tried them once and they weren't too bad, but again I think it's all about shaping. After a recent trip to Europe and watching the locals going to the bakery morning and afternoon to buy baguettes as it's such a staple, makes me want to have that tradition here at home.

Are there any projects you are working on that you’d like to share with us?

Hot Cross Buns is our immediate project. We want to work on a recipe that we love before Easter. The only drawback will be once we have them sorted everyone will want them. 

What advice do you have for new bakers?

Grace: Get yourself a dutch oven as the results will be much better than putting it straight into a normal household oven. It made a world of difference for us. 
 
Mark: Relax. It's four ingredients. Flour, water, salt and TIME. If it's feeling sticky or stiff just give it longer in the autolyse and fold times. If it's not rising, just give it longer. Don't put yourself under too much pressure and try to rush it. It will happen. Find one recipe and stick with it. We started with a 3:2:1 recipe until we had it under control. Use it as time to chill out. There's only one thing better than making the bread, and that's sitting down to share it with those close to you.

entry.title: Interview with a Baker - Kristen
entry.summary: In our “Interview with a Baker” series, we ask artisanal bakers from…
entry.content:
In our “Interview with a Baker” series, we ask artisanal bakers from across the globe with different backgrounds to answer twenty questions about their experience with sourdough and baking in general. The questions the bakers answer range on topics from their baking history to specific techniques they use in their bread making process.

 
 
Hello, Kristen. Tell us a little about yourself, your background and who you are.
Hi, I’m Kristen, 38 years old. I work in a telecommunications field but bake in my spare time. As a kid I wanted to be a chef when I grew up. Cooking and baking have always been my favorite hobbies. 
 
How can we find you on social media?   
On Instagram, my profile is @the_dough_eyed_girl
 
Do you have a website or blog or perhaps a video sharing platform you'd like to share? 
Other than this one, I have a website for a local food swap here in my city. Alexander
built that site as well. 
 
 
Where in the world are you located?
I live in Wilmington, Delaware, US. 
 
What inspired you to explore sourdough? 
Well, I love bread. Good bread is not cheap. It’s also harder to find than it should be. So last year I started getting back into baking more, and along with that came pizzas, sticky buns, and bread. The more I baked, the more I was on Instagram looking at what other bakers were doing.  I got really interested in trying my hand at it. I was inspired by what I saw online. The crumb shots, and the scoring, and all the words that I had no idea what they meant, it fueled me to keep diving deeper. 
 
How long have you been making bread, and specifically sourdough bread?  
I made my first loaf of sourdough bread towards the end of 2018. It was very recent. I grew up with a mom who used to bake with me often. We made a few different kinds of breads with some regularity. We also used to make pizza when I was a kid from scratch a lot.
 
What has been the hardest part of learning how to make sourdough for you? 
Getting my starter to bloom in winter. I’m not really used to failing in the kitchen, but my first starter failed miserably. I’m not even going to lie, I was pretty annoyed about it. The problem I think was I complicated it. I kept seeing people making starters with apple juice or pineapple juice or kombucha. Guess what, that did not work for me at all. So, I stalked to bunch of bakers online and noticed most of them simply used water and flour and that worked out just fine. So my second attempt was 50/50 mix of flour and water and 11 days later, one thermal sock turned sourdough sleeping bag later, I had a live and active sourdough starter and was making my first loaf of bread. 
 
What is your personal style with regards to making sourdough bread? 
My style is still a little bit all over the place I think, but I guess we could call it experimental.  Because I’m still new to sourdough, I’m trying to improve so many skills and techniques, while simultaneously trying to experiment with many ingredients and flavor combinations in my head.
 
What’s your routine for refreshing and maintaining your starter? 
I feed my starter daily a mix 50/50 mix of water and flour. I use King Arthur All Purpose flour and their whole wheat flour in an even mix. I don’t keep a large amount of starter on hand. I’ve read many times over that 250 grams is the magic volume of starter to keep on hand that will live a long and happy life, but for now at least, I keep about 70 to 90 grams total. During the week I feed my starter once a day 30 grams of flour and 30 grams of water, but when I’m going to be making bread the next day I do a morning and a night time feeding. I also have not yet tried putting my starter in the refrigerator, but I do plan to move to that model in the next month or so. 
 
How soon before mixing your dough do you start your autolyse?
I don’t think I’m ever consistent with this. My first loaf of bread was a 30 minute autolyse and the bread I started today was a 4 hour autolyse. I do try to do them for about 2 hours or more because I’m always shocked and impressed at the amount of gluten that developed. 
 
What is your favorite grain to work with?  
I guess I’d have to say rye, but I don’t feel like I’ve tried enough kinds of wheat yet to be able to properly answer this. 
 
What is your preferred technique for developing gluten in your dough once it’s mixed together? 
My favorite may be coil folds, simply because I like the way the dough looks when I’m doing it. I think it makes a little dough butt and it makes me giggle every time like a child. Coil folds only work for me with higher hydration doughs, so if I’m working with a lower hydration dough, I do basic stretch and folds. 
 
Once I finish mixing the autolyse, starter and salt together, I do my first set of coil folds or stretch and folds about a half hour later. I repeat this again about 30 minutes later, then again for the third time about 45 minutes after, and the last set I do about an hour after that. 
 
Do you prefer the ambient or retarded method of baking? 
I have not actually tried the ambient method of baking. I really like letting the dough ferment overnight in the fridge. One of these days I’ll give it a try just so I can understand first hand the differences in flavor. 
 
How long do you let your dough proof for? 
It’s been a rather cold winter where I am, and I have not baked sourdough bread during the summer months yet, so all of my proofing times will change with the seasons. 
From the time I finish mixing the dough, till the time it goes into the fridge, it’s about 5 hours of proofing time. Once it’s in the fridge I keep it in there for at least 14 hours. Sometimes I push it longer depending on what’ going on in my morning. I just like to do my bakes early in the morning which is why I don’t let them go longer. 
 
What do you use to score your bread? 
I’m super cheap and have not been able to bring myself to buy a proper lame yet, so I have been using a utility blade for most of my bakes. Eventually, I’ll invest in one of the many amazing lames that exist out there. 
 
How do you bake your typical bread? (Dutch oven, steam oven, loaf pan…) 
I bake most of my loaves inside a 5 qtr. cast iron, non-enameled, Dutch oven. I preheat my oven to 500f / 260c for about an hour with the Dutch oven inside. My oven tells me it’s hot after about a half hour, but I want the Dutch oven to be as hot as possible so I just let it preheat longer. Once the oven is hot enough, I take the dough out of the refrigerator and turn it our onto parchment paper and score it. I transfer it into the bottom of the Dutch oven, cover with the lid and put into the oven for 25 minutes. After that I take off the lid and turn the temperature down to about 450f / 232c and cook it for 18 to 23 more minutes.  I base my decision on when to pull it from the oven based on the color of the crust. If I want a darker loaf, I just leave it in a bit longer. 
 
What is your favorite use for sourdough discard? 
Sourdough Pancakes!!! Without a doubt! I found a recipe online from Taste of Lizzy and it’s the single best pancake recipe I’ve ever tasted. Do yourself a favor and check out their site and make it!
 
I keep a mason jar in my fridge and all week I add my discard to it. By Friday I have plenty of discard to make something fun with. 
 
How do you see yourself expanding your sourdough skills in the future? Are there new skill you want to master?
I’m reading books by bakers like Vanessa Kimbell from The Sourdough School, and Tartine Bread by Chad Robertson. I also plan to invest in a home grain mill in the next year or so. I started looking at ancient grain seeds online at one point when I ambitiously contemplated trying to grow my own grains, but I live in a city and really don’t think that’s the kind of thing that works well in planter boxes. 
 
Are there any projects you are working on that you’d like to share with us?
Excuse me while I self promote our site for a moment, but I’m excited for things to come. Alexander and I have worked hard on a redesign plan sourdoughbake.com. You will be seeing a redesigned homepage soon, followed by a full redesign of the baker's percentage calculator as well as a chat platform and more. 
 
What advice do you have for new bakers? 
I guess I’d say, relax and just enjoy the learning process. Don’t focus on your crust, crumb or scoring and don’t compare you bread to that which you see on Instagram. When you do your first bake, find ONE single guide and follow it. If you watch 9 hours of videos on how to make a loaf of bread and then you try to combine all the things you saw, you are likely going to feel frustrated when your bread does not turn out like you expect. Find one guide who you like and mimic what they do. Learn in increments and explore on your own terms. Ultimately, remember the thing that makes a successful loaf of bread is that you enjoy eating it.

entry.title: Interview With a Baker - Tammy Jones
entry.summary: In our “Interview with a Baker” series, we ask artisanal bakers from…
entry.content:
In our “Interview with a Baker” series, we ask artisanal bakers from across the globe with different backgrounds to answer twenty questions about their experience with sourdough and baking in general. The questions the bakers answer range on topics from their baking history to specific techniques they use in their bread making process.
 
Hello, Tammy. Tell us a little about yourself, your background and who you are.
Hello! I'm Tammy, 49 years old. I work as an environmental attorney in Southern California for a major utility company, but I spend my weekends baking sourdough. I've been cooking and baking since I can remember, but sourdough is really something I am passionate about and I love to work with local millers to the extent I can. Keeping things local, and sharing with my community is something very important to me.
 
How can we find you on social media? 
On Instagram, my profile is @breadbakinggirl. I am also part of the Speakeasy Bakery Community here in Santa Clarita.
Do you have a website or blog or perhaps a video sharing platform you'd like to share? 
Nothing other than above.    
 
Where in the world are you located?
Stevenson Ranch, California, US.
 
What inspired you to explore sourdough? 
My dad is a diabetic, but loves bread. We found that when he eats sourdough, he doesn't have blood sugar spikes so I just kept baking it. That and I was raised in part near San Francisco, so I grew up loving that sourdough "tang". Also, I'm borderline obsessed with following such great bakers on Instagram and each time I see something new I find I just have to try it myself!
 
How long have you been making bread, and specifically sourdough bread?  
On and off for five years, but intensely and weekly for a year now.
 
What has been the hardest part of learning how to make sourdough for you? 
Figuring out the proofing and finding space in my fridge to hold everything! I love to bake in large amounts, usually 8-10 loaves at a time, and I don't have the kitchen appliances to support my obsession. I've been living with a broken oven for two years now, so having to juggle with limited oven and fridge space has been a challenge. Also, shaping batards! I have no idea why, but boules seem to come more naturally to me.
 
What is your personal style with regards to making sourdough bread? 
I like to keep my bread fairly rustic, as I do my cooking. I find that my bread baking style has naturally conformed to my cooking style. I'm not overly artistic, although I did spend a year or so painting, so you'll probably never see beautifully artistic scoring from me, but I know it tastes good. I'm also really passionate about working with different grains, particularly ancient grains, so my bread always contains a lot more "wheatiness" than others.
 
What’s your routine for refreshing and maintaining your starter? 
I keep two starters regularly, a white and a wheat. Always in the back of my fridge in Weck jars. We like our sourdough more on the sour side, so the fridge is my friend. I always mix and bulk on Saturday and bake on Sunday. So on Wednesday I take "thing" and "wheat thing" ("sweet thing is my chocolate starter that I pull out during the holidays) out of the fridge and start feeding them twice a day and three times on Friday to get them super active for the weekend. I generally keep about 200 grams of each total.
 
How soon before mixing your dough do you start your autolyse?
Depends on the grain, some grains like spelt, don't necessarily require a long autolyse. But generally at least two hours, often as long as four.
 
What is your favorite grain to work with?  
Right now Einkorn. I adore the nutty flavor and the tangy aftertaste. I also love how versatile it is.
 
What is your prefered technique for developing gluten in your dough once it’s mixed together? 
I always do stretch and folds every 30 minutes for the first couple hours, and do a couple coil folds after each stretch and fold. I love coil folds, there is something very relaxing about them! I also do a pretty vigorous kind of "pseudo" slap and fold in the bowl right after mixing, until the dough starts to smooth out a bit and gets sticky.
 
Do you prefer the ambient or retarded method of baking? 
Always retarded for me, again, the sour.
 
How long do you let your dough proof for? 
It depends on the grain, whole grains ferment a lot faster, but typically I bulk for about four hours after mixing and then divide, shape and put in the fridge for anywhere between 12 and 30 hours.
 
What do you use to score your bread? 
Tyler's Wire Monkey UFO lame!!
 
How do you bake your typical bread? (Dutch oven, steam oven, loaf pan…) 
Almost always in a Lodge combo cooker. Unless I'm baking baguettes or large batards, then on a pizza stone with lots of steam. Sometimes I'll pour hot water over dish towels and put them in a roasting pan under the pizza oven to really steam things up.
 
What is your favorite use for sourdough discard? 
Sourdough pancakes. I always have a batch of batter next to the stove on the weekends.
 
How do you see yourself expanding your sourdough skills in the future? Are there new skill you want to master?
I'm going to try lamination next, plus I've been thinking about milling my own grains. I'm really fortunate to have Grist & Toll just a couple miles from my office. They are one of the only millers local to this area, and lucky for me, one of the best around in general, so I haven't had to mill my own, but I might give it a try one day.
 
Are there any projects you are working on that you’d like to share with us?
Not yet.
 
 
What advice do you have for new bakers? 
Learn your grains, they aren't all the same and need to be treated differently. Remember, there isn't really such a thing as "white" flour, it's all wheat, just extracted differently. Also, keep detailed logs of what works and what doesn't. I've been keeping a baking diary for years, and refer to it constantly. Finally, just learn to trust your instincts, and get a good thermometer. Time and temperature are the two most important variables in sourdough.

entry.title: The Dairy Experiments
entry.summary: This past weekend I experimented with dairy in my breads. Over three…
entry.content:
This past weekend I experimented with dairy in my breads. Over three days I made 2 loaves with different combinations of ingredients.  I have no idea how they would turn out because I only googled it long enough to know that there was a chance it would produce a beautiful bread and there's also a chance the enzymes in dairy would degrade the gluten structure.  I'm not really trying to prove any theory correct or not, I just want to find our first hand how they would turn out.


The first loaf I did make had 5 varieties of flour in it, which I know is a lot.  They were on sale and now I’m going nuts with my combinations. If you wanted to make a version of this bread at home, just adjust the ratios below (link to baker's percentage post) to move as many kinds of flour as you like. The thing that really made this bread special is that the main liquid in it is whole milk, sweetened with a rose  infused honey and vanilla bean.

Loaf 1 Baker's Percentage Grams
Bread flour 60% 286
Rye flour 10% 47
Oat flour 10% 47
Spelt flour 10% 47
Wheat Germ 10% 47
Hydration (milk) 82% 380
Starter 20%  95
Salt 2% 10

The second bread is more than half bread flour, with a healthy mix of King Arthur white whole wheat and some wheat germ. The liquid in this dough autolyse was half whole milk and half cultured buttermilk.

Loaf 2 Baker's Percentage Grams
Bread flour 63% 299
White whole Wheat flour 26% 123
Wheat Germ 11% 52
Hydration (Milk & Buttermilk) 78% 360
Starter 20% 95
Salt 2% 10

 So as implied by the title here, this bread experiment was supposed to be about how dairy impacts the sourdough making experience. As you may have guessed already, the way I kicked off this experiment was not ideal. When you are doing an experiment, you should change one variable, not every possible variable. What I should have done is made bread with the same grain mix that I’m used to working with in the same hydration level that I know. Instead, I jumped into this and changed up everything possible. Five kinds of flour? No. Don’t do experiments this way. The first loaf was by no means a disappointment for me, it was just too much going on for me to be able to tell what differences in the final result were triggered by which variable.  Was the crumb tight because of the grains or because of the milk?

Let’s talk about how dairy made things different. First off, the hydration felt way off. It felt dryer than what dough of the same hydration felt like with water. With the first loaf, I thought it was possibly because some of the grains absorbed differently than I’m used to, but I do not think that’s the case as the second loaf also felt dryer than I expected. I suppose I really should do one more dairy test and use only bread flour and see how that one feels. I’ll keep you all posted on that.

The hydration was not the only thing that felt different. There was a different texture to this bread. It was tender and had a tight crumb. The enzymes in the dairy did degrate the gluten in my dough, but not necessarily in a bad way. The texture was pleasant, still felt like bread, but lost some of the chewiness.  

The flavors of both loaves were sweeter than I am used to. It was subtle, but noticeable. Neither the milk nor the buttermilk left behind any scent once they were baked.

All in all, I have to be honest and say, I’m not sure I’d make bread with milk very often. There’s nothing wrong with this bread at all, and I’m sure someone reading this will absolutely love the way these loafs came out, but personally, I missed the chewy texture. Midway though this past week I found myself lusting after other people's breads on instagram. I wanted something with more texture than I had. Still, I’m pretty sure I;m going to make at least one other loaf with milk in it in the near future.

entry.title: Baker's Math
entry.summary: Baker’s math. If you are like how I used to be, you…
entry.content:
Baker’s math.

If you are like how I used to be, you probably saw some beautiful bread posts online with captions like, “70% bread flour, 30% wheat, 70% hydration, 1.8% salt” and they left you wondering what new version of math equaled up to 171.8%. After much research, nagging many fantastic bakers, and watching more YouTube videos than I can keep track of, I finally figured out the secret to understanding baker’s math and why it’s important.

Baker’s math, helps you understand the recipes, and let’s you adapt someone else’s recipe to your taste. Simply put, it is the recipe that the baker use to make their bread. Instead of being in cups or grams, it’s measured in percentages. It breaks the bread down into its most basic parts, flour, hydration, salt and starter (There can be more ingredients but we are keeping it simple). This way it allows us to scale up or down a recipe - which will tell us how many grams of an ingredient we will need.

The key to understanding baker's math lies in the flour. It is of course the most important part of your bread. In baker’s math, flour is always represented as 100%. We can look at the example I mentioned above: 70% bread flour, 30% wheat, 70% hydration, 1.8% salt. You’ll notice there are two types of flour being used, and their percentages add up to 100. If we made a bread that had 4 cups of bread flour, in baker’s math, that would be represented as 100% bread flour. If you had a recipe that called for 200 grams of bread flour, 200grams of rye flour, 200grams of all-purpose flour and 200grams of spelt, those 800 grams would also be represented as 25% bread, 25% rye, 25% all purpose, 25% spelt flour.

The total weight of all your flour is the starting point for every other percentage in the formula. But for the other percentages to mean anything, you need to determine how much flour you are going to use.



Hydration; typically this just means water. We will talk about other liquids that can be added to breads in a future post. For now let’s just assume that when you see hydration, it means water. In baker’s math, the total amount of water in a recipe is compared to the amount of flour. The simplest example would be if you had half as much water as you do flour, then you would have 50% hydration. I think the sweet spot for new bakers is between 65% and 70% hydration, depending on what kind of bread you are making. Higher hydration doughs are much stickier but can produce larger holes in your bread, or as we call it in the baking world, a larger crumb.

Let’s take a moment and look at an example. I use about 475 grams of flour to make one loaf of bread. I know I want to make a 75% hydrated loaf. Step one would be to determine that 75% of 475 (grams of flour) is 356 grams of water.

We will cover the arithmetic below, but assume you want to use 20% of starter in this formula. Still using the same total weight of flour, we now figure out the weight of the starter. 20% of 475 would mean that you would need 95 grams of starter.

Keep in mind that our starters are made of water and flour. We know that half of that 95 grams of starter is water weight, which needs to be subtracted from the Total Water weight to determine how much water needs to be added when mixing. In this case, to get the total of 356 grams of water, we need to subtract 47 grams of water from the total (since that amount is coming from our starter) which means that 261 grams is the amount of water you need to weigh and add to your dough.

Total weight of flour (grams) 475
Desired Hydration percentage 78%
Total Water Weight (gr) 370.5
Desired Starter percentage 20%
Total Starter (grams) 95
Weight of water from starter 47.5
Total Water Needed (total water - starter) 323
Desired Salt percentage 2%
Total Salt Needed (grams) 9.5


Congratulations, you now understand the most “complicated” part of bakers math. All that we have left to cover is starter and salt and those are just additional ingredients calculated based on the total amount of flour. Since we are on the subject, let's talk about our sourdough starter.

Typically, bakers use a 20% ratio of starter to flour when they bake. If you just did the math in your head to figure out 20% of 475, then you get an A+ for the day.

20% of 475 grams of flour is 95grams, which is the total starter weight in grams you are going to be adding to your dough.

Salt is the exact same thing. Typically the amount of salt added into a loaf is between 1.8% and 2.2%. It’s a personal choice you need to make based on your taste preferences and your relationship with salt. Yes, you can bake breads with 1% of salt or less, but they will be fairly bland. Still, at the end of the day, you are the one who will be eating your bread, so use the percentage you are comfortable with. 



There it is folks, baker’s math in a nutshell. Now when you are browsing your favorite social sites, planning the amazing sourdough bread you are going to make, bakers math will help you be able to replicate their loaves. Our Baker's Percentage Calculator can help you easily do all the math needed to replicate, scale up or down a recipe that you see online. Once you are comfortable with making bread, it will help you build out and test your own custom bread making formulas. Take a look and give our baker's percentage calculator a try.

entry.title: Welcome
entry.summary: Hello all, Kristen here. We wanted to take a minute to welcome…
entry.content:
Hello all, Kristen here. We wanted to take a minute to welcome you, and give you a little bit of information about who we are and what Alexander and I want to do here at Sourdough Bake.

Alexander and I met last year on Instagram and bonded over our common love for the art of making sourdough bread. Both of us were fairly new at bread making, but when I needed help getting my starter to spring to life, he was there to help me figure out ways to keep it warm enough to develop. We have been arguing over the best ways to raise our starters and bake our breads ever since.

We both spend our 9-5’s Monday – Friday working in different tech fields. I manage wireless telecom for corporations and Alexander runs a web development company. He also does all the design, development, and back end work on this site, as I’m not allowed to touch anything that I could break. Honestly, that’s a good decision on his part, but don’t tell him I said that.

For both of us, making sourdough bread is a way to decompress after a long work day. It’s an opportunity for us to get away from formulas and rigid structures of our jobs and use our hands and senses to create beautiful and delicious bread. We find freedom in the unlimited combinations of grains and techniques that go into our breads.

Alexander already had built his Baker’s Percentage Calculator when I came into his world, but it was not long before I was giving him my opinions on how it could be improved and expanded upon (Editor's note: It’s so cute that she believes that). During that conversation, we realized just how many ideas we each had in our heads that the other one could help make real. We decided to partner up and work together to create new bakers tools, recipes, blogs and more.

Over the next few months you will start to see more things happening here at sourdoughbake.com. This new blog Alexander created for us is just the first addition. We can’t wait for you to see what else is coming.
